byline.contributor: Reporting was contributed by Falih Hassan and Ahmed Salah from Baghdad, Kamil Kakol from Sulaimaniya, and employees of The New York Times from Kirkuk, Najaf, Hilla and Diyala Province.

abstract: Collapse of oil prices puts Iraqi economy into crisis, shrinking government’s monthly revenue from $8 billion to less than $3 billion per month and affecting eight million pensioners and government employees; officials consider deep spending cuts, end to subsidies and institution of tax system to make up shortfall; significant impediments exist to all solutions on table.
lead_paragraph: The country depends on oil for 90 percent of its revenue. Now, it faces crippling budget cuts and increasing difficulty paying government workers.

headline.main: Battered by War, Iraq Now Faces Calamity From Dropping Oil Prices
headline.print_headline: Iraq’s New Threat: Calamity From Falling Oil Prices

snippet: The country depends on oil for 90 percent of its revenue. Now, it faces crippling budget cuts and increasing difficulty paying government workers.

keywords.value: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
